Getting started

Source: vignettes/getting-started.Rmd
getting-started.Rmd
library(bitmexr)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyquant)

The following examples demonstrate how bitmexr can be used to obtain trade data from BitMEX, and used with other packages such as tidyqaunt to explore and visualise the data.

Core functions

The core of the package are the trades() and bucket_trades() functions.

trades() collects data regarding individual trades that have been executed on the exchange.

# Get 1000 most recent trades on the exchange

trade_data <- trades(symbol = "XBTUSD",
                     reverse = "true",
                     count = 1000)

bucket_trades collects trade data which has been summarised into the follow time frames: 1-minute, 5-minute, 1-hour and 1-day. Given the large volume of trades performed daily on the exchange, this function is preferred over trades() if you want to obtain data spanning many days.

# Daily OHLC data from 2017-01-01 to 2020-01-01

bucket_data <- bucket_trades(binSize = "1d",
                             startTime = "2018-01-01",
                             endTime = "2020-05-01")

For more fine grained data, you may want to specify a smaller time frame.

# 1-minute buckets from 2020-01-01 until 2020-01-10

bucket_data_long <- bucket_trades(binSize = "1m",
                                  startTime = "2020-01-01",
                                  endTime = "2020-01-05")

max(as.Date(bucket_data_long$timestamp))
#> [1] "2020-01-01"

However, the maximum date returned is still the first day. This is because the maximum number of rows returned per API call is 1000. To obtain the desired 5-day sample, the bucket_trades() function would need to be called multiple times. To make this easy, the package provides map_* variates of the two core functions.

Using map_* variants

Take our desired 5-day time period again. Using map_bucket_trades() will create the necessary number of API requests to satisfy the time frame automatically.

bucket_data_long <- map_bucket_trades(binSize = "1m",
                                      start_date = "2020-01-01",
                                      end_date = "2020-01-05")
#> 6 API requests generated.
#> Current limit = 30 requests per minute

max(as.Date(bucket_data_long$timestamp))
#> [1] "2020-01-05"

A progress bar is provided in the console to provide some information regarding the expected duration for the function to complete.

The map_trades() function works in a similar way, however because the number of trades per day is not known in advance, it is not possible to estimate how long the function will take. Instead, this function prints the maximum timestamp from each API call to provide an indication of how long is left.

map_trades(start_date = "2019-05-03 12:00:00", end_date = "2019-05-03 12:10:00") %>% 
  select(1:5) %>% 
  head()
#>  Getting trade data between 2019/05/03 12:00:00 and 2019/05/03 12:10:00 
#> 
 Current progress:  2019/05/03 12:01:11
 Current progress:  2019/05/03 12:01:44
 Current progress:  2019/05/03 12:03:15
 Current progress:  2019/05/03 12:05:08
 Current progress:  2019/05/03 12:05:53
 Current progress:  2019/05/03 12:08:13
 Current progress:  2019/05/03 12:09:53
 Current progress:  2019/05/03 12:13:36
#>                  timestamp symbol side size  price
#> 1 2019-05-03T12:00:09.576Z XBTUSD Sell   18 5700.0
#> 2 2019-05-03T12:00:13.595Z XBTUSD Sell 1000 5700.0
#> 3 2019-05-03T12:00:13.689Z XBTUSD Sell 5500 5700.0
#> 4 2019-05-03T12:00:13.718Z XBTUSD  Buy  100 5700.5
#> 5 2019-05-03T12:00:13.800Z XBTUSD Sell  900 5700.0
#> 6 2019-05-03T12:00:13.992Z XBTUSD Sell 2000 5700.0

The function stops when the start_date is greater than the end_date. This results in a slightly greater sample than intended, but ensures the full time frame is captures by the function call.

Note: A warning is given when time frames of greater than 1 day are passed into the function. Due to the large number of trades executed on the exchange each day, this function should only be used for specific time intervals of interest. Using map_bucket_trades() is a much better option for time intervals spanning multiple days.

Use with other packages

Once data has been obtained, it is possible to use packages such as the excellent tidyquant to explore/visualise the data further.

bucket_data_long %>%
  filter(timestamp > "2020-01-01" & timestamp < "2020-01-03") %>%
  mutate(timestamp = as_datetime(timestamp)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = timestamp, y = close)) +
  geom_candlestick(aes(open = open, high = high, low = low, close = close)) +
  geom_ma(ma_fun = SMA, n = 200) +
  scale_x_datetime(date_breaks = "12 hour", date_labels = "%H:%M") +
  theme_tq()

See the tidyquant vignette for more details https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=tidyquant
